questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in her right thumb and wrist that radiates to her elbow. It is worse when she holds her 7-month-old son and improves with the use of an ice pack. Six months ago, she slipped on a wet floor and fell on her right outstretched hand. Her mother takes methotrexate for chronic joint pain. The patient takes ibuprofen as needed for her current symptoms. Examination of the right-hand shows tenderness over the radial styloid with swelling but no redness. There is no crepitus. Grasping her right thumb and exerting longitudinal traction toward the ulnar side elicits pain. Range of motion of the finger joints is normal. There is no swelling, redness, or tenderness of any other joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skier's thumb, also known as gamekeeper's thumb, is a result of injury to the ulnar-sided collateral ligament of the thumb. This condition is usually caused by a fall on the thumb and manifests with pain and swelling over the MCP joint of the thumb. The examination would show laxity of the thumb's MCP joint on the ulnar side (i.e., hyperabduction) and a weak pinch grip. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

A boutonniere deformity can occur secondary to trauma or rheumatoid arthritis. It is characterized by injury to the extensor mechanism of the finger and classically manifests with hyperextension of the DIP and flexion of the PIP. Boutonniere deformity of the thumb is seen as hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.
Image Description:

Characteristic appearance of the ring finger with flexed PIP and hyperextended DIP joints

This condition is the result of injury to or slippage of the central band of the extensor digitorum, usually caused by trauma (e.g., sports injury) or chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.

C) CORRECT:

De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common cause of wrist pain in adults and is more common in women, particularly in new mothers due to the repeated strain of lifting the baby. While the exact pathophysiology is unknown, it is attributed to repetitive activities involving postures that maintain the thumb in extension and abduction. Diagnosis of this tendinopathy is established by the physical exam findings of pain over the radial styloid and a positive Finkelstein test. Treatment is usually conservative and involves oral NSAIDs, rest, splinting, and corticosteroid injections.
Image Description:

The examiner holds the patient's thumb in flexion and applies ulnar deviation to the wrist. The test is positive if the patient feels a sharp pain over the first extensor tendon compartment (along the distal radius). This finding is pathognomonic for de Quervain tenosynovitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Swan neck deformity is typically seen in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis that affects the finger joints. The examination would show hyperflexion of the DIP and hyperextension of the PIP. Swan neck deformity of the thumb is seen as hyperflexion of the interphalangeal joint and hyperextension of the MCP. This patient has none of these clinical features.
Image Description:

Proximal interphalangeal joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal joint flexion

E) INCORRECT:

Mallet finger is a closed extensor tendon injury typically caused by a sudden hyperflexion of the DIP (forced flexion) usually from a direct blow to the tip of the finger (e.g., baseball hitting the tip of the finger). The examination would show a loss of extension of the DIP of the affected finger, with the DIP remaining in a flexed position at rest. This patient has none of these clinical features.
Image Description:

Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP joints

This condition results from sudden forced hyperflexion of the DIP joint while the digit is extended (particularly common in sports such as basketball and baseball), which causes rupture or avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon.

F) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is characterized by sensorimotor disturbances (i.e, paresthesia, weakness) in the area of the hand innervated by the median nerve (i.e., the thumb, index, middle, radial border of the ring finger). The paresthesia can be elicited by passively flexing the wrist (positive Phalen sign). The symptoms this patient presents with are inconsistent with a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome.

G) INCORRECT:

Stenosing tenosynovitis, also called trigger finger, usually affects patients in their 5th or 6th decade, and females are more commonly affected. Although the thumb is frequently affected, the patient would typically present with painful locking of finger in a flexed position which is suddenly relieved by a snap/pop on extension. The examination would show tenderness and a palpable nodule at the base of the metacarpophalangeal joint. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.
questions.hint: A positive Finkelstein test is pathognomonic for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man reports pain in his right thumb and wrist for the past 6 weeks. Two months ago, he started a new job bagging groceries, but the wrist pain makes it difficult for him to carry the bags, especially when he tries to carry a bag by supporting the bottom of it with his wrist and forearm.. He states that he has not experienced numbness, tingling, or preceding trauma.
Physical examination reveals tenderness and mild swelling over the radial styloid. You can induce severe pain by asking the patient to open his hand loosely and then grasping the thumb and using it to sharply deviate the hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger. He has no symptoms with percussion over the volar side of the wrist.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s wrist pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome causes pain, tingling, and numbness in the first three fingers and can be brought on by flexion of the wrists (Phalen maneuver) or percussion over the median nerve on the volar side of the wrist (Tinel sign).

B) INCORRECT:

Carpometacarpal arthropathy can cause pain in a similar location but should not lead to swelling along the radial styloid, which suggests tenosynovitis.

C) CORRECT:

Pain, tenderness, and swelling along the radial side of the wrist, coupled with a positive Finkelstein test (pain in the radial wrist that is exacerbated by asking the patient to open his hand loosely and then grasping the thumb and using it to sharply deviate the hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger), is highly suggestive of de Quervain tenosynovitis. This condition, characterized by myxoid degeneration (rather than inflammation) within the tendon sheaths of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, can be caused by repetitive strain of the thumb and wrist.

Key learning point: Pain in the wrist that is exacerbated by asking the patient to open his hand loosely and then grasping the thumb and using it to sharply deviate the hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger, is consistent with a diagnosis of de Quervain tenosynovitis.
Image Description:

Noninflammatory thickening of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis in the first dorsal compartment of the extensor retinaculum, overlying the radial styloid process.

D) INCORRECT:

A distal radial fracture is unlikely without trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow causes numbness and tingling in the fourth and fifth digits.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old healthy woman reports a one-month history of pain that is localized to the base of her right thumb and radiates up her forearm with movement. She notes that the pain is worse when she opens a jar, makes a fist, or lifts up her 3-month-old grandchild, whom she has been caring for during the past month. The pain is sometimes relieved by ibuprofen.
The patient denies any morning stiffness, joint swelling, finger numbness or tingling, or pain in any other joints. She cannot recall any recent trauma.
When the patient’s right thumb is extended, pressing on the base of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons reproduces her discomfort.
A radiograph of the right wrist shows no evidence of osteoarthritis.
Which one of the following tests or signs is best for diagnosing her condition?

choices.text: Grip the metacarpal bone of the thumb and move it in a circle while placing axial force
Ask the patient to open her hand loosely, then ask her to grasp her thumb and use it to sharply deviate her hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger
Place a sheet of paper between the thumb and forefinger and attempt to pull it away
Tap firmly on the volar surface of the wrist
Place the backs of the hands together and maintain full wrist flexion for 2 minutes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The axial grind test (gripping the metacarpal bone of the thumb and moving it in a circle while placing axial force) is used to diagnose osteoarthritis at the first carpometacarpal joint, but this patient does not show evidence of osteoarthritis on radiograph.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's history and symptoms are consistent with de Quervain tenosynovitis, which involves myxoid degeneration (rather than inflammation) within the tendon sheath surrounding the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus tendons. This condition is most frequently caused by chronic overuse of the wrist and hand, often from lifting a baby repeatedly.

The Finkelstein test is used to diagnose de Quervain tenosynovitis. It involves asking the patient to open their hand loosely and then asking them to grasp their thumb and sharply deviate their hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger. The presence of pain constitutes a positive test for de Quervain tenosynovitis.

The Eichhoff test is commonly confused as the Finkelstein test but is less specific for de Quervain tenosynovitis. It involves bending the patient’s thumb across the palm of the hand, covering it with the fingers in a loose fist, and then bending the fist with ulnar deviation toward the fifth finger.

Key learning point: The physical examination maneuver that can be used to diagnose de Quervain tenosynovitis is the Finkelstein test, which involves asking the patient to open their hand loosely and then asking them to grasp their thumb and use it to sharply deviate their hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger.

C) INCORRECT:

The Froment paper sign (flexion of the flexor pollicis longus of the thumb to maintain grip pressure when a paper is pulled from the thumb and forefinger) is a test for ulnar-nerve palsy, but this patient is unlikely to have this condition because she does not describe hand weakness or numbness of her fourth or fifth fingers.

D) INCORRECT:

The Phalen test (placing the hands together and maintaining full wrist flexion for 2 minutes) and the Tinel sign (tapping on the volar surface of the wrist) are used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome, which is compression of the median nerve. This diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of a history of paresthesias.

E) INCORRECT:

The Phalen test (placing the hands together and maintaining full wrist flexion for 2 minutes) and the Tinel sign (tapping on the volar surface of the wrist) are used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome, which is compression of the median nerve. This diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of a history of paresthesias.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old postpartum woman reports having pain in her right wrist for several weeks. She has never experienced this pain before and says she has no other joint involvement. She notes no overt wrist swelling but points to a painful area over the bony prominence on the radial aspect of the wrist. She says the pain is making it difficult for her to pick up her 2-month-old son and perform other simple activities. She denies morning stiffness. She has no history of trauma to the wrist or hand.
Her right wrist is not swollen or warm. She is tender to palpation over the radial wrist but not at the base of the thumb. She has normal and nonpainful flexion and extension of the wrist, but when she tucks her thumb into her fist and attempts to move her wrist in the ulnar direction, she experiences significant pain. In addition, when she is asked to open her hand loosely and the examiner grasps her thumb and uses it to sharply deviate the hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger, she experiences severe pain. No other joints are involved, and the rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.
What is the most likely cause of this patient's wrist pain?

choices.text: Osteoarthritis of the thumb carpometacarpal joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually causes more-generalized hand pain and neuropathic symptoms; Tinel and Phalen tests are often positive, whereas the Finkelstein test is negative.

B) CORRECT:

De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common wrist problem. It occurs more often in women, particularly those of childbearing age during the postpartum period. Thought to be caused by overuse of the thumb and wrist, it involves the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons in the area of the radial styloid.De Quervain tenosynovitis is diagnosed with reproducible pain upon performing the Finkelstein test. This test involves asking the patient to open his or her hand loosely and then grasping the thumb and using it to sharply deviate the hand in the ulnar direction, toward the fifth finger. The Finkelstein test is more specific for de Quervain tenosynovitis than the Eichhoff test, in which the patient’s thumb is tucked into the fist, with the examiner then moving the wrist in the ulnar direction.

Key learning point: A postpartum woman who reports wrist pain and exhibits reproducible pain on the Finkelstein test is likely to have de Quervain tenosynovitis.
Image Description:

The examiner holds the patient's thumb in flexion and applies ulnar deviation to the wrist. The test is positive if the patient feels a sharp pain over the first extensor tendon compartment (along the distal radius). This finding is pathognomonic for de Quervain tenosynovitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Carpometacarpal arthritis, another cause of pain on the radial side of the wrist, can be difficult to distinguish from nearby tendinitis. However, in this young, recently postpartum woman with a positive Finkelstein test, de Quervain tenosynovitis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

In this patient, the absence of a history of trauma makes navicular fracture and wrist sprain unlikely diagnoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with navicular fractures (also known as scaphoid fractures) have pain and tenderness in the anatomical “snuff box” on the radial side of the wrist. These fractures are often caused by falling on an outstretched hand. In this patient, the absence of a history of trauma makes navicular fracture and wrist sprain unlikely diagnoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with navicular fractures (also known as scaphoid fractures) have pain and tenderness in the anatomical “snuff box” on the radial side of the wrist. These fractures are often caused by falling on an outstretched hand. In this patient, the absence of a history of trauma makes navicular fracture and wrist sprain unlikely diagnoses.
questions.hint: This condition is also common in golfers, tennis players, individuals who frequently text, and in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of pain in her right thumb and wrist that radiates to her elbow. The pain worsens when she holds her 7-month-old son and improves with ice application. Six months ago, she slipped on a wet floor and fell on her right outstretched hand. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the radial styloid of the right hand, without redness or crepitus. Grasping her right thumb and applying longitudinal traction toward the ulnar side reproduces her pain. Range of motion in the finger joints is normal. No other joints are swollen, red, or tender. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mallet finger is a closed extensor tendon injury typically caused by a sudden hyperflexion of the DIP (forced flexion) usually from a direct blow to the tip of the finger (e.g., baseball hitting the tip of the finger). The examination would show a loss of extension of the DIP of the affected finger, with the DIP remaining in a flexed position at rest. This patient has none of these clinical features.

B) CORRECT:

De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common cause of wrist pain in adults and is more common in women, particularly in new mothers due to the repeated strain of lifting the baby. While the exact pathophysiology is unknown, it is attributed to repetitive activities involving postures that maintain the thumb in extension and abduction. Diagnosis of this tendinopathy is established by the physical exam findings of pain over the radial styloid and a positive Finkelstein test. Treatment is usually conservative and involves oral NSAIDs, rest, splinting, and corticosteroid injections.

Key learning point: De Quervain tenosynovitis presents as pain over the radial styloid, worsened by thumb movement, and is commonly seen in individuals performing repetitive thumb abduction and extension.
Image Description:

The examiner holds the patient's thumb in flexion and applies ulnar deviation to the wrist. The test is positive if the patient feels a sharp pain over the first extensor tendon compartment (along the distal radius). This finding is pathognomonic for de Quervain tenosynovitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is characterized by sensorimotor disturbances (i.e, paresthesia, weakness) in the area of the hand innervated by the median nerve (i.e., the thumb, index, middle, radial border of the ring finger). The paresthesia can be elicited by passively flexing the wrist (positive Phalen sign). The symptoms this patient presents with are inconsistent with a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Stenosing tenosynovitis, also called trigger finger, usually affects patients in their 5th or 6th decade, and females are more commonly affected. Although the thumb is frequently affected, the patient would typically present with painful locking of finger in a flexed position which is suddenly relieved by a snap/pop on extension. The examination would show tenderness and a palpable nodule at the base of the metacarpophalangeal joint. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Skier's thumb, also known as gamekeeper's thumb, is a result of injury to the ulnar-sided collateral ligament of the thumb. This condition is usually caused by a fall on the thumb and manifests with pain and swelling over the MCP joint of the thumb. The examination would show laxity of the thumb's MCP joint on the ulnar side (i.e., hyperabduction) and a weak pinch grip. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.
questions.hint: A positive Finkelstein test is pathognomonic for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old office manager presents with a 4-week history of wrist pain that began gradually after increasing her workload. The pain is located over the dorsoradial aspect of the wrist and worsens with thumb movement. She has tried over-the-counter ibuprofen with minimal relief. On examination, there is tenderness over the radial styloid process. A photograph of the physical examination maneuver that causes pain over the dorsoradial wrist is shown. She asks about returning to work tomorrow for an important project deadline. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Thumb spica splinting and activity modification

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI is not indicated for noninfectious tenosynovitis, which is a clinical diagnosis. Imaging is reserved for suspected underlying systemic disease or diagnostic uncertainty.

B) INCORRECT:

While thumb spica splinting is part of conservative management, glucocorticoid injection is the preferred initial treatment and is more appropriate, given this patient's unsuccessful trial of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and functional needs.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral is premature because this patient has not yet received appropriate conservative management. Surgery is reserved for severe or refractory symptoms after 6 weeks of conservative treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has De Quervain tenosynovitis based on the clinical presentation and positive Finkelstein test. Glucocorticoid injection into the affected tendon sheath is the most appropriate initial treatment for De Quervain tenosynovitis, with effectiveness in approximately 80% of patients. This is likely to provide more effective symptom relief than splinting alone, and is an appropriate next step given the patient's insufficient response to NSAIDs and need for rapid functional improvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Carpal tunnel release addresses median nerve compression and is not indicated for De Quervain tenosynovitis, which affects the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons in the first dorsal compartment.
